content:
RECALLING THE DAY THE WAR ENDED IN EUROPE

On May 8th, 1945, the war ended in Europe---and the world went wild. At least those nations that were on our side.

The American troops in Europe, the English and French celebrated----and so did millions of Americans at home.

But the story was somewhat different for those of us in the armed forces in the Pacific. I remember how, on my little ship, we were happy about the surrender of Germany and the suicide of Adolph Hitler. But, as we heard on the radio about the joyous celebrations in America, many members of our crew on the USS PC 470. wondered: “What about us? Don’t they know there’s a war on here??”

Indeed, the fleet we were part of was preparing for an assault on the home islands of Japan. And our battle plan anticipated that there would be one million American casualties. Hardly an easy figure to digest!

This was three months before the atomic bombs were dropped and the Japanese emperor sued for peace. So we were expecting a tough and bloody fight against the fiercely determined Japanese Army and Navy.

In Europe, on May 8th, German troops gave up their arms to the Allies. The Germans didn’t surrender to the Russians until May 9th. In America, President Harry Truman proclaimed that May 13th, Mother’s Day, would be a day of Thanksgiving. “Our rejoicing is sobered and subdued,” he said, “by a supreme consciousness of the terrible price we have paid to rid the world of Hitler and his evil band.”

In England, Prime Minister Winston Churchill, appeared on a flag-draped balcony in London and told a cheering crowd: “God bless you all!” And the people sang: “For he’s a jolly good fellow!”

In New York, a cheering crowd overflowed Times Square. The city’s skyscrapers showered down the heaviest deluge of ticker tape and other assorted debris since the American hero Charles Lindbergh, was hailed in a parade up lower Broadway in 1927.

Thousands couldn’t stop celebrating. In the garment district, they hurled thousands of bolts of cloth into the streets along with phone books . They danced. They sang. And many cried: “It’s over! It’s over!”

One soldier, it’s reported, cried out: “What are they hollerin’ about? It ain’t over!”

Fiorello LaGuardia, the feisty mayor of the city, scolded the celebrants in a broadcast over loudspeakers. He ordered them to go back to work.

It dawned on some people that the war wasn’t over, that tough, dangerous times still lay ahead. But, although the boys and girls in the Pacific might not agree, it was indeed a time to celebrate.

content:
GEORGE POLK---A REPORTER WHO DIED SEARCHING FOR TRUTH

George Polk was a courageous young reporter who was murdered in Greece just 69 years ago. He was trying to cover the Greek civil war, a battle between Greek government forces and Communist insurgents.

His body was found in Salonika Bay in northern Greece on May 16, 1948. Polk, a protege of Edward R. Murrow, was regarded as a hero by the journalists of that day---and indeed, in his name, Long Island University still gives awards each year to enterprising reporters.

The news of Polk's death stunned the journalistic community of that era. Polk was an appealing figure. He was just 34 years old. He has covered stories in China and Europe. He enlisted in the Navy after Pearl Harbor and flew combat missions in the Solomon Islands. He was a reporter who often resisted government, or official, sources of news, when he suspected there was an effort to cover up the facts. His search for truth was apparently what killed him.

Kati Marton, in her book "The Polk Conspiracy" claimed that the Greek government at that time assassinated Polk because he was digging into a rightist conspiracy that included hiding funds for the personal use of a Greek politician in a New York bank account. Time has obscured the details of Polk's quest for truth---but his memory lives on.

So long as journalists pursue the truth George Polk's name will stand out. He was young, impetuous, strong-willed. But, above all, he will be remembered for his courage.

content:
THE 17TH OF MAY DAY---NORWEGIANS’ 4TH OF JULY 

To Norwegians----it’s their Fourth of July…..

They call it 17th of May day---and they have been celebrating it since 1814. It marks the day when Norway won its independence and established its constitution. Inspired by America’s constitution, this document is the second oldest democratic constitution in the world. 

I have a special feeling towards this day. For my wife, Vera, an immigrant from Norway, and I used to celebrate it right here in Brooklyn. 

A thriving Norwegian-American community existed in Bay Ridge for decades. And our son, Michael, from the time he was four years old, helped us celebrate the 17th of May Day for many years. We would go to Bay Ridge to see the parade, which went down Third Avenue and Bay Ridge Avenue and Fifth Avenue to 67th Street, where the reviewing stand was set up for the parade.

It was a colorful parade with people attired in Norwegian costumes dating back to the 19th century. The women wore beautiful bunas, dresses adorned with embroidery, in many colors, each representing a different section of Norway. 

Michael waved little American and Norwegian flags. Both flags carry the colors red, white and blue. And, indeed, the framers of the Norwegian constitution modeled it after our own constitution. It has imbued Norway with a spirit --- they call it the spirit of the 17th of May---that is devoted to freedom and democracy. It inspired Norway to resist the Nazi German invasion in World War II, with determined underground fighters battling the invaders and, in many cases, sacrificing their lives.

The Bay Ridge celebration, which aims to encourage “a deep appreciation of the ideals of independence and freedom,” is a festive occasion. It is associated with spring and the coming of summer---a most significant day in a country coming out of a frigid winter.

In Norway, there are parades. The children have a starring role. Hot dogs, soda and ice cream are on the menu. Near the sea and rivers, eating salmon and trout is part of the celebration. In New York, over the years, Norwegian-Americans have celebrated with Viking helmets, cowboy hats and home-made costumes.

This year the holiday will be celebrated on the nearest Sunday to the 17 of May, the 21st, in Bay Ridge, and it will feature a parade starting at 80th Street and Third Avenue.

Probably the emotions Norwegians and their relatives here experience on May 17th is best expressed in Norway’s national anthem: “Ja, vi elsker dette landet….” In English, the words begin: 

“Yes, we love this country

As it rises forth,

Rugged, weathered, above the sea, 

With the thousands of homes

Love, love it and think of our father and mother 

And the saga night that sends

Dreams to our earth….”
